Today, the House Committee on Education and the Workforce voted on three important bills to return power and flexibility to patients.  Key in our efforts today is the Small Business Health Fairness Act, which I am proud to cosponsor.  Small businesses have been hit particularly hard by Obamacare’s mandates, high costs, and limited choices. Small business owners – who want to provide health care for their employees – frequently tell me that they are struggling to do so because of Obamacare.  The Small Business Health Fairness Act would level the playing field for small businesses by allowing them to band together to increase bargaining power to get lower health insurance costs for their employees.   In addition, this bill includes strong protections for patients with pre-existing conditions, a top priority of mine and my colleagues as we work through the health care reform process.

As high winds blow through the area, please take a look at the following storm information and be sure to share with your family and friends.  Stay safe everyone!   The winds are forecast to continue until 7 - 8 p.m. tonight and additional outages are expected.  Safety is always a priority. Stay at least 20 feet away from all power lines and anything they may contact, and consider them live. They are extremely dangerous. Treat every downed power line as if it is energized. Heed the warning of yellow caution tape, which indicates there is a downed power line in the area. DO NOT CROSS YELLOW CAUTION TAPE.   DTE Customers have three ways to contact DTE during an outage. Customers can report an outage, check on the status of an outage and view an outage map from their smart phones using the DTE Energy Mobile App, which is available free of charge from the Apple Store or Google Play. DTE encourages customers to use the website at dteenergy.com as well. Customers can also call DTE at 800-477-4747 to report power outages or downed lines.   Storm Tips:   ·   Never drive across a downed power line. If a power line falls on your vehicle, remain inside until help arrives. ·   Always operate generators outdoors to avoid dangerous buildup of toxic fumes. ·   Turn off or unplug all appliances to prevent an electrical overload when power is restored. Leave one light switch on to indicate when power is restored. ·   Don’t open refrigerators or freezers more than absolutely necessary. A closed refrigerator will stay cold for 12 hours. Kept closed, a well-filled freezer will preserve food for two days. ·   If a customer is elderly or has a medical condition that would be adversely impacted by a power outage, they should try to make alternative accommodations with family or friends.

Earlier today, I spoke on the House floor to express my disappointment that Congress needed to resort to a massive funding bill to prevent a government shutdown.  The choice before us was stark and binary: we could vote to shut the government down, or we could vote for this massive funding bill.    Neither was a good option, but shutting the government down would stall military pay, and send a sign of weakness to the world.  At a time when North Korea is becoming increasingly aggressive, Europe is unstable, and Russia is posturing, we cannot afford to shut down.  This was a hard vote, but unavoidable at this point. We must continue to pay our troops and other uniformed personnel.    Though imperfect, this legislation funds some critical programs including an increase in defense spending, funds to fight ISIS, increased resources for border security, funds to fight the opioid epidemic, and cancer research funding.  It also includes funds for the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative and funds to study the potential invasion of Asian carp into the Great Lakes – both are important programs for Michigan.   Given today’s options, I voted to keep our government open, but I am calling on my colleagues to end the series of short term funding measures, address the shortcomings in our appropriations process, and develop better solutions for the future.

Today, the House of Representatives passed the American Health Care Act.  Families living under the Affordable Care Act have seen their premiums, copays, and deductibles continue to rise. Doing nothing was not an option.    I know from business; rarely can you achieve the ‘perfect’ deal. Perfect doesn’t exist in negotiation.  Over the past few weeks, changes have been made to improve the American Health Care Act.    This final legislation delivers relief from the burdens of the Affordable Care Act, while reaffirming our commitment to ensuring all Americans have access to care.  The American Health Care Act eliminates the Affordable Care Act’s mandates and taxes and establishes a system of incentives through tax credits, rather than punishing individuals for not purchasing insurance.    Those who do not already receive coverage from their employer, Medicaid, or Medicare, are eligible for tax credits to help them purchase insurance.   It has long been a priority of mine to ensure that all Americans, especially those with the highest health care needs and costs, are protected. This legislation targets funds directly to support those who need it most.  Giving states the flexibility to make that happen is critical to lowering premiums and guaranteeing access for everyone.

As a father of six, I am all too familiar with the struggle that comes with the college decision-making process for prospective students and their families.  Choosing whether to go to college, and how to pay for it, is one of the most important and costly decisions in a young person's life, made more difficult by all the uncertainties involved.  Currently, you can find more information about a washing machine you're thinking of buying than you can find about an educational major at a college or university. LEGISLATIVE ALERT: The House just passed two important public safety bills.   - Kate’s Law, is named after a young woman in San Francisco who was senselessly murdered by an illegal immigrant who had been previously deported several times, and reentered the United States every time.  Kate’s Law would enhance the current maximum sentences for illegal reentry for criminal aliens who illegally reenter the United States.   - The No Sanctuary for Criminals Act would deny Sanctuary Cities eligibility for certain federal grants and would allow the families of victims like Kate Steinle to sue jurisdictions who release aliens who later commit a murder, rape, or felony with a sentence of a year or longer.  This bill also includes Sarah and Grant’s Law, named after Sarah Root and Grant Ronnebeck. This provision would ensure an alien be detained after the alien is arrested for or charged with a crime that caused death or serious bodily injury of another person.  This would prevent what occurred in Sarah Root’s case, where an unlawful immigrant who was driving while drunk crashed into Sarah’s car, was freed on bond by the State while Sarah was in the hospital.  By the time Sarah died of her injuries, the alien was long gone and has not been seen since.
